title: R40474
content: This report analyzes recent laws and congressional proposals related to gun regulation in the District of Columbia. Key statutes and bills include federal provisions, the D.C. Firearms Control Regulation Act, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, and the Firearms Control Amendment Act. Congressional proposals often coincide with discussions on voting rights for the District. The report discusses congressional proposals to amend the District of Columbia's gun laws, specifically Title II of S. 160 from the 111th Congress and H.R. 645 from the 112th Congress. It analyzes the impact of these proposals on DC firearms laws following the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller, which affirmed an individual's right to possess a firearm for self-defense within the home. In District of Columbia v. Heller, the Supreme Court affirmed an individual's right to possess a firearm for self-defense within the home, declaring unconstitutional three provisions of the District's Firearms Control Regulation Act. In response to the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller affirming an individual's right to possess a firearm for self-defense at home, the DC Council enacted emergency legislation to amend the city's gun laws. This led to the Firearms Control Emergency Amendment Act of 2008, which faced criticism for not fully complying with the Heller decision. Additionally, H.R. 6691, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, was introduced in Congress to potentially loosen provisions of the District's existing gun laws. H.R. 6691, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, was introduced in response to the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller. It aimed to overturn or loosen provisions of the District's existing gun laws. The proposal was later adopted into H.R. 6842 but did not become law. Senator John Ensign also introduced an amendment using the language of H.R. 6842, which was approved by the Senate but faced stalled movement. The Firearms Control Amendment Act of 2008 (FCAA) and the Inoperable Pistol Amendment Act of 2008 (IPAA) were passed by the DC Council and transmitted to Congress for approval. These acts amended firearms provisions in the DC Code and imposed new restrictions on firearm regulation and ownership. The amendments were challenged but upheld in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia in 2010. The DC Code was amended by the FCAA and IPAA, which imposed new restrictions on firearm regulation and ownership. These amendments were challenged but upheld in court. Congressional legislation like H.R. 645 seeks to overturn some of these provisions while considering the new acts. While Congress can still legislate for the District and impose limits on its authority, the Act allows the DC Council to amend laws passed by Congress. Section 3 of H.R. 645 and Title II-S. 160 impose limits on the District of Columbia's authority regarding firearms. The District cannot prohibit or unduly burden individuals from acquiring, possessing, transporting, or using firearms for lawful purposes. Private ownership or use of firearms cannot be discouraged or eliminated by the District's laws or regulations. The proposed language in H.R. 645 and S. 160 limits the District of Columbia's authority on firearms, ensuring that individuals can acquire, possess, transport, and use firearms for lawful purposes without being discouraged or eliminated by the District's laws.
